<extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is activated by <extra_id_0> many cytokines and growth factors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> such as the <extra_id_0> IL-6 family of cytokines <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-11 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> leukemia inhibitory factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> oncostatin M <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> platelet-derived growth factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> epidermal growth factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , in addition to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 4 ] , but previous studies have demonstrated that <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is <extra_id_0> the major factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA synovial fluid <extra_id_0> that <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces constitutive activation of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in mononuclear cells [ 31 ] .

Since <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is also abundant in sera of active RA patients , frequently detected at > 1 ng / ml [ 27 ] , we examined whether persistent exposure of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells to high concentrations of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the blood circulation was responsible for their sustained <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation and resistance to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition in active RA .

Both <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation was activated by <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells ( data not shown ) , in agreement with previous observations [ 4 ] .

Normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells were thus incubated for 20 min with culture medium containing 30 % serum from active RA patients and neutralizing anti - <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody or control antibody , and STAT phosphorylation was examined by western blot analysis .

RA serum was able to induce tyrosine phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but not <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and this <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation was mostly abolished by neutralization of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity ( Fig . 5a ) .

These results indicate that <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the dominant <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activating <extra_id_0> factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> contained in sera of active RA patients .

The lack of <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation by RA serum suggests that much higher concentrations of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be required for <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation as compared with <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , or that inhibitors of <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling may be present in RA serum .

We next examined whether <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could suppress the effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to inhibit <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .

After preincubation with or without 10 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for 36 hours , normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells were stimulated by CD3 and <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulation in the presence or absence of 1 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for 36 hours , and the <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was measured by ELISA .

<extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pretreatment of normal cells reduced <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated inhibition of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production ( Fig . 5b ) , indicating that high concentrations of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could modulate T-cell responsiveness to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Taken together , these findings suggest that persistent exposure to serum <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may have a role in both the induction of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation and the resistance to the inhibitory effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .
